title: ‘Strangled with her own swimsuit’
text:
Share on Twitter 
INVESTIGATORS from the Federal Bureau of Investigation have flown to Panama after a young tourist was found brutally murdered at a popular beach resort. 
Columbia University graduate and New York native Catherine Johannet, 23, had been reported missing on stunning Bastimentos Island in the Bocos de Toro region three days earlier. 
Local TV station Nex Noticias is reporting that the killer tore off Ms Johannet’s “pareo rosado” (pink swimsuit) and used it to strangle her. 
Authorities are currently questioning eight people in connection with the slaying after carrying out a series of raids across Bocas del Toro, according to the Spanish language La Prensa newspaper. 
However, the killer is not believed to be among those detained and is the subject of a massive manhunt across the stunning Central American archipelago. 
Ms Johannet’s devastated siblings Laura and Paul arrived on Bastimentos Island yesterday to help search for their missing sister only to be told she had been found murdered. 
The young woman had been staying at a hostel on Colon Island but set off for a day trip to Red Frog Beach on nearby Bastimentos on February 2. Stunning Red Frog Beach on Bastimentos Island where Catherine Johannet was found murdered Source: Supplied Catherine Johannet’s killer is on the run somewhere in the Panama Islands Source: Facebook 
The hostel owner contacted police at about 10pm that night when she still hadn’t returned. A police officer found her body “in a wooded area near Bastimentos’ shore” on Sunday, La Prensa said. 
Ms Johannet was no naive tourist but a seasoned world traveller who had recently completed a stint steaching English in Vietnam. Her last social media post suggested she was having the time of her life in Panama when tragedy struck. 
“I found paradise and it’s called Isla Ina,” she wrote on Instagram on January 28 alongside a selfie of her beaming on a beach. 
Tributes for the young woman have started flowing, with family and friends posting moving tributes on Facebook. 
“We love and miss her dearly,” her brother Paul wrote. 
“She was a world traveller — by the age of 23, she had already visited 6 continents and innumerable countries, including a recent 18-month trip to Vietnam where she taught English Literature to local students. Catherine Johannet’s last Instagram post on January 28. Picture: Instagram Source: Instagram 
“She was cheerful, adventurous, thoughtful and warm — all qualities I strive towards. I’ll always look up to my youngest sister.” 
Ms Johannet’s older sister Laura posted details of a funeral service to be held at Scarsdale Congregational Church in New York on Saturday. 
Her parents have left a sign addressed to the media on the front door of the family home that reads: “Our family is in the midst of grieving. We ask you to respect our privacy. We respectfully decline to comment any further at this time. Please vacate the premises.” Catherine Johannet had recently spent 18 months teaching English in Vietnam. Picture: Facebook Source: Instagram Ms Johannet’s siblings flew to Pamana to look for her, only to discover she had been murdered. Picture: Instagram Source: Instagram
